meanings.definition: To lower in importance or value.
meanings.sent1: I had to downgrade my favorite toy to make room for the new one.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to downgrade their product due to poor sales.
meanings.sent3: When my little brother broke my toy, I had to downgrade it to a 'fixer-upper'.
meanings.sent4: Her careless actions caused her reputation to downgrade rapidly.
meanings.sent5: The storm's damage would downgrade the once beautiful garden to a mess.

meanings.definition: A situation in which something is made less important or valuable.
meanings.sent1: The downgrade of the old building led to its demolition.
meanings.sent2: The downgrade of the currency affected the economy negatively.
meanings.sent3: The downgrade of the movie's rating made it a comedy instead of a drama.
meanings.sent4: The downgrade of the antique vase made it less desirable to collectors.
meanings.sent5: The downgrade of the software caused frustration among users.

meanings.definition: To assign a lower security rating to a financial asset.
meanings.sent1: The bank had to downgrade the bond due to market fluctuations.
meanings.sent2: Investors were concerned when the agency decided to downgrade the stock.
meanings.sent3: The decision to downgrade the security rating left many investors worried.
meanings.sent4: The company's financial troubles forced them to downgrade their assets.
meanings.sent5: The analyst's report recommended to downgrade the investment for better risk management.
